title: Royal Guard Fiora Refund post-VU?
body: With the drastic change in the look of Royal Guard Fiora can we request refunds for the skin?

replies.body:
Hiya SpaceMonkey3000,

Unfortunately, we are no longer offering refunds for post-reworked/updated content. For more information regarding the decision, check out [this](http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=4572524) Red Post.
You should for this skin, since you drastically changed it.

Riot's too arrogant to do such a thing. It's not like they have to give us a refund in money spent. A refund in RP is good enough. But Riot probably too lazy to refund the many unsatisfied players. It's their indirect way of "shove it and get over it." =\ Riot became less about the players two years ago, when they started getting all these new faces.

here is the relevant Terms and Service passage from section IV OWNERSHIP which unless a person is somehow playing the game without signing them they have to accept anything stated there

B. Game Assets, Riot Points and Virtual Items. When using the Game, you may accumulate in-Game assets associated with your Account, including, without limitation, objects, artifacts, currency, items, equipment, and/or other value or status indicators (“Game Assets”) that reside on servers operated by Riot Games as data. You acknowledge and agree that such Game Assets are accumulated as part of your Account and therefore you shall have no ownership or other property interest in any of those Game Assets. **You further acknowledge and agree that Riot Games has the right, but not the obligation, to delete, alter, move, remove, or transfer any and all Game Assets, in whole or in part, at any time and for any reason, with or without notice to you, and with no liability of any kind to you.** Riot Games does not provide or guarantee, and expressly disclaims any value, cash or otherwise, attributed to any data residing on servers operated by Riot Games, including without limitation the Game Assets associated with your Account.



THIS 
>  You further acknowledge and agree that Riot Games has the right, but not the obligation, to delete, alter, move, remove, or transfer any and all Game Assets, in whole or in part, at any time and for any reason, with or without notice to you, and with no liability of any kind to you.

Means that riot has no responsibility to tell you of the changes or responsibility to compensate you for the changes.

It is still a really douchey move. Consider a few things:

1 - Skins are purely cosmetical. Meaning you buy skins for looks and looks only. Meaning once those looks get changed drastically you literally lose the thing that you paid for.
2 - Players don't have to pay to play this game in full. Which means that people who are paying for already overpriced skins are doing so in support of Riot. And by making such big changes and not offering refunds, Riot gives a big slap in the face to those same people who  support them.

And not only is it douchey - but also from business point of view this is a terrible decision. Say, a person bought a 975 RP skin, and it gets changed. The person asks for a refund. From here there are 2 possibilities.

1 - Riot gives a refund. They don't lose money since refund is not in real world currency, but in in-game one. Person spends it on another skin they like, and maybe they buy RP in the future.
2 - Riot does not give the refund. Person is rightfully pissed off, and thinks for themselves: "If a piece of content I bought can get changed in the way I don't like it anytime, why should I even buy content?". And thus Riot loses a paying customer.

I know I've stopped supporting Riot in monetary way long time ago because of this. And I'd recommend to anyone else to do so.

I am not to judge whether or not something is "douchey" I was just stating the proof that shows that they are completly within their legal right to even remove royal guard fiora and give no compensation, whether or not people like that or not they have agreed to the fact that nothing involving the game belongs to them and that they get no compensation whatsoever. In fact it would be possible for Riot to simply remove all champions but yasuo and there is no way to say that they are overstepping their legal boundries because everyone signed a document saying that they accept that.
And this is 100% the reason I stopped buying RP.

This. If I know that a skin I like can be changed anytime into something completely different - sorry, Riot. You are not getting my money.

And the changes are drastic more often than not. This new RG Fiora is completely different: new face, hair, clothes, hat and sword.

It's sad that they can charge for something, then completely change it, and shrug when it isn't the same thing someone paid for.

That's how you lose even more trust (don't know if you have noticed, but Riot is in surprisingly short supply of that the past few years). Annoying people like this is a good way to get that person to be less likely to buy a skin the next time they have the money for RP.

Riot doesn't seem to think that far ahead.

Here's the thing, and the most important thing with that:

Riot, and not you, own the content, and as such, can do with it as they please.

The same with any other software you buy from any company, you're not actually paying for the thing; you're paying for the rights to use the thing (yeah, those text boxes you click "agree" on after every patch? That's what I'm talking about). They are doing what they feel is best for the game, which by the way, is their sole source of income. They *are* thinking far ahead, and it's instead you that aren't.

To take a current example, in a few years, Riot might feel the need to update the HUD again, and just as drastically as thy did this time. How do you think the player base is going to react? Exactly the same as they are now, with people complaining about how it's so much different, and how they can never get used to it, yada, yada, yada.

You and me, if we are still playing when that time comes, will have the privilege to sit back and watch, laughing as we see how stupid the people complaining about the HUD now were.

There are always people that will get attached to something, but that is by no means a justification to leave something that the creator believes is poorly designed in the game. If, as Riot says, they eventually, after many years, go back and rework already reworked and updated champions, and they do so to Fiora, then there will be the exact same backlash as there is today.

Here's the thing, and the actual most important thing with that:

You pull stuff like this, and you continue to do so, you annoy your PAYING customers.  

When you sell a product to someone, who trusts you as a company enough to spend money on a product that isn't even physical, and they KNOW they don't "own", then turn around and change it with no feedback (when nothing was wrong with it to begin with) and turn your nose when it annoys them, they aren't going to just keep paying you for products in the future. 

It has nothing to do with attachment, it has nothing to do with ownership, it has nothing to do with "hating change", it has to do with treating people paying for your product with respect and earning and keeping trust. If you continuously change, and swap, and remove features a person pays for, they eventually start to lose trust. 

It might be one person liking the previous Fiora skin because they bought it for whatever reason, and it changes, and now they don't like it. They might be looking at a new skin and going "hm, I can buy rp, but if I buy this now, will they just change it later?" and put their card away, or go spend that money elsewhere. that is one instance and one example, but there are examples of it all over the place you could make, different people, different skins/champions, etc etc. 

Sure you can't please everyone, but what's the point of pissing someone off because of this fact? Sure 1 person might not seem like a lot, but one loud voice can catch the attention of 10 people, then 10 loud voices can catch the attention of 10 each, and so on. One person with an instance like this can get the attention of others and then they say "yeah, that is shitty. What if they did that to what I like?".

You might be fine to argue and defend Riot's shifty actions, but there are an equal amount that are more than happy to keep their hard earned money, and eventually the lost trust will build up until they never pull their wallet out again (like with me not buying rp in over a year and a half).

----

Also the OP wasn't having an issue with Fiora's rework, that wasn't and isn't an issue. The issue was the skin, which realistically made no sense to update or change, because her skins (especially in game model wise) were pretty good, especially compared to a large portion of the terrible ones they still haven't fixed like pizza feet Taric/Morde who they could have spent time fixing, instead of annoying people messing with Fiora, who was perfectly fine.

"Riot, and not you, own the content, and as such, can do with it as they please."

While they _can_, as is technically their right given the EULA, it is not necessarily a good thing doing it.
If Riot pisses off - or rather, pisses _on_ - enough people, who then will provide monetary support to them, which I can only assume is what's paying their bills?

Any company wishing to be in the business should know they can only line their own pockets at the expense of their customerbase for so long before it's all over (is exploit too strong a word?). And from what's I've seen, it's gone pretty much downhill over the last couple of years.

I could even have sucked up the increased RP prices if I had been given something, even just a small token, in return, such as another refund every year (still got 2 left, but that's not the point).

Unfortunately, I am no longer buying RP from your shady corporation due to the fact that you sell me one thing and then you change it into something else that I do not want later on.  For more information regarding this decision please consult your bosses on their dickery.

I really think you guys in HQ need to think about Fiora a bit...

General consensus (at least on the boards, I mean if we're the only ones against it and everyone's all for it, ignoring us isn't as much of an issue) seems to be that her new look is a downgrade. Hell, some of us here have showed people who don't play the game or know the characters the old and new models/splash, and most of the time they get it reversed. That... should say something, dude.

I hate to say it, but sometimes you need to do something instead of going by the books. I'm no professional, I can't tell you guys how to do your jobs, but I can tell you as a customer that I will not be satisfied having paid for a satisfying product, only for it to be "updated" to look like crap. It's like I ordered a gourmet meal, had it placed in front of me, only for the waiter to come midway through my meal and switch it out for a hamburger, then told that I have to pay the gourmet price even though the end result isn't what I paid for. 

You guys have options, but going strictly by policy might not be the best approach. People have suggested having a traditional skin, which I've heard Riot doesn't want to do for any champion update, but Fiora's appearance has *completely* changed. Hell, comparing the new to old classic splash, one of them could easily be a skin. They're that different. 

Look, some of us aren't satisfied. You can ignore us, or you can listen and do *something* to help us out here. You have our money and RP in the end, so it sucks to be us, but you could earn trust and admiration from the playerbase if you came up with an ingenious idea that game developers would be talking about for years on end when discussing player relations.

Don't jump the shark.

They don't do refunds for reworks anymore. All champions and skins are subject to change (older are more likely of course), so be aware of that before you make a purchase.
---
> http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=4572524
Hey all,
>
Over the past two years we've been ramping up our ability to steadily modernize champions' art, background and gameplay, to the point where champion updates have become an integral part of the overall evolution of League of Legends. When we first began making these updates we were mindful of the fact that we were altering content to which players might be very attached, and with that in mind we agreed to the handful of refund requests from the passionate players who owned updated champions and who sent a ticket to Player Support. 
>
Back then we could do these individual gestures of goodwill because the number of refund requests was pretty low. Requests came largely from players who mained the champ. Once the policy was made public, there was a 10,000%+ spike in requests. We looked at the data and found that a very large majority of requests were from players who werent actively invested in the champion pre-update, but were trying to get back RP or IP without using a refund token.
>
To give you an idea of the impact, every recent champion update has resulted in a storm of support tickets larger than what we typically see from a full day of major server instability. Combine this with the fact that we're on pace to double our annual number of champion updates (6 in 2013, already 7 in first half of 2014) and it begins to significantly impact Player Support's ability to handle critical issues like account recoveries and tech support.
>
As a result of these factors, we've decided that beginning with the Karthus champion update, we will stop processing refund requests for updated champions. It would be awesome to have a process that specifically targets those players significantly impacted by an update and doesn't interfere with Player Support's ability to quickly solve vital support issues, but we are far off from a good solution to this.
>
We know this may be disappointing for some players, particularly those actively playing and invested in updated champions. To help address this issue, the champion update team is working on increased transparency (http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/champions-skins/txxQETbY-champion-updateupdate ) when it comes to which champions they're working on. Additionally, the Player Support team has created a central hub (https://support.leagueoflegends.com/entries/40116190-Champion-Rework-Schedule ) with info on past, present, and future champion updates. These efforts should both help you plan your purchases and use of refund tokens and give you better places to voice your feedback and help us fine-tune updates. 
>
If you have any questions about this change, please leave them below and we'll do our best to address them.

---

Basically, only a small fraction of players that request a refund for updates/reworks actually use that champion or skin. The rest are people that already regretted their choice and are using the change as an opportunity to avoid the consequences of buyer's remorse.

I asked this already and I was told the same.  If I buy something, I expect to get what I paid for.  If I purchase something from an artist because I like it... and a year later the artist dislikes his old style... he doesn't get to come into my house, rip up my art and draw me a new one in the new style that he now prefers to use.  That isn't what I paid for!  What's more... I don't LIKE the new style.  I would never have paid for it!  I don't want it.

You took my money for something, then swapped it out for a turd and said "Oh, lol... our policy is not to give refunds".  The compassion shown for their playerbase is staggering here.  And the worst part is, riot is big enough now to just... not care.  They don't need to.  As little as it would take to refund a handful of people for a skin... they won't.  Because they don't need to.  The anger over this won't affect their income in the least.  And that's what it's about... income.  They're either concerned that enough people would ask for refunds that it would actually be a problem for them... a blip on the radar of their profits.  In which case... maybe realize what this means about the quality of the product you're forcing down our throats and fix it!  

Alternately, they just don't want their players to think that they can call them on their products.  EVER.  This is... slightly more understandable, since people will gripe and demand refunds over every stupid thing... but so what?  If enough people dislike the skin that you're changing... either don't change it or give them back their money!  Don't flip the bird to the players who bought the skin in the first place.  Show your fans you give a crap about them.
